front.div:
Abstract Up to the end of the nineteenth century, phenol was recovered primarily
from coal tar. With the commercialization of the phenolic resins, the demand for
phenol grew significantly. Currently, the cumene-to-phenol process is the predomi-
nant synthetic route for the production of phenol. It is accompanied by acetone as a
co-product. Cumene is oxidized with oxygen to form cumene hydroperoxide. The
peroxide is subsequently decomposed to phenol and acetone, using a strong mineral
acid as catalyst. The products are purified in a series of distillation columns. The
cumene-to-phenol process is described in more detail in this chapter. An overview
is given about synthetic routes via direct oxidation of benzene. None of these
alternative routes has been commercialized. The chapter also gives an overview
of global supply and use of phenol in 2008. Finally, the main natural sources and
synthetic routes for cresols, xylenols, resorcinol, and bisphenol-A are described.
These components are used as comonomers for special phenolic resins.
